bandos motus Lunares, erat (per Prop.

XXV. hujus) ad vim
gravitatis apud nos, ut 1 ad 638092, 6. Et vis TM-LM&longs;eu
2PKin Syzygiis Lunaribus, e&longs;t duplo major.

Hæ autem vires,
&longs;i de&longs;cendatur ad &longs;uperficiem Terræ, diminuuntur in ratione di­
&longs;tantiarum a centro Terræ, id e&longs;t, in ratione 60 1/2 ad 1; adeo­
que vis prior in &longs;uperficie Terræ, e&longs;t ad vim gravitatis, ut 1 ad
38604600. Hac vi Mare deprimitur in locis quæ 90 gradibus di&longs;tant
a Sole.

Vi altera quæ duplo major e&longs;t, Mare elevatur & &longs;ub Sole
& in regione Soli oppo&longs;ita.

Summa virium e&longs;t ad vim gravitatis
ut 1 ad 12868200. Et quoniam vis eadem eundem ciet motum,
&longs;ive ea deprimat Aquam in regionibus quæ 90 gradibus di&longs;tant à
Sole, &longs;ive elevet eandem in regionibus &longs;ub Sole & Soli oppo&longs;itis,
hæc &longs;umma erit tota Solis vis ad Mare agitandum; & eundem
habebit effectum ac &longs;i tota in regionibus &longs;ub Sole & Soli oppo­
&longs;itis Mare elevaret, in regionibus autem quæ 90 gradibus di&longs;tant
a Sole nil ageret.

Hæc e&longs;t vis Solis ad Mare ciendum in loco quo vis dato, ubi Sol
tam in vertice loci ver&longs;atur quam in mediocri &longs;ua di&longs;tantia a
Terra.

In aliis Solis po&longs;itionibus vis ad Mare accollendum, e&longs;t
ut &longs;inus ver&longs;us duplæ altitudinis Solis &longs;upra horizontem loci di­
recte & cubus di&longs;tantiæ Solis a Terra inver&longs;e.

Corol.Cum vis centrifuga partium Terræ à diurno Terræ motu
oriunda, quæ e&longs;t ad vim gravitatis ut 1 ad 289, efficiat ut alti-
tudo Aquæ &longs;ub Æquatore &longs;uperet ejus altitudinem &longs;ub Polis men­
&longs;ura pedum Pari&longs;ien&longs;ium 85820; vis Solaris de qua egimus, cum
&longs;it ad vim gravitatis ut 1 ad 12868200, atque adeo ad vim illam
centrifugam ut 289 ad 12868200 &longs;eu 1 ad 44527, efficiet ut al­
titudo Aquæ in regionibus &longs;ub Sole & Soli oppo&longs;itis, &longs;uperet alti­
tudinem ejus in locis quæ 90 gradibus di&longs;tant a Sole, men&longs;ura
tantum pedis unius Pari&longs;ien&longs;is & digitorum undecim cum octava
parte digiti.

E&longs;t enim hæc men&longs;ura ad men&longs;uram pedum 85820
ut 1 ad 44527.

PROPOSITIO XXXVII. PROBLEMA XVIII.
Invenire vim Lunæ ad Mare movendum.

Vis Lunæ ad Mare movendum colligendà e&longs;t ex ejus propor­
tione ad vim Solis, & hæc proportio colligenda e&longs;t ex propor­
tione motuum Maris, qui ab his viribus oriuntur.

Ante o&longs;tium
fluvii Avonæad lapidem tertium infra Bri&longs;toliam,tempore verno
& autumnali totus Aquæ a&longs;cen&longs;us in Conjunctione & Oppo&longs;itione
Luminarium (ob&longs;ervante Samuele Sturmio) e&longs;t pedum plus mi­
nus 45, in Quadraturis autem e&longs;t pedum tantum 25. Altitudo
prior ex &longs;umma virium, po&longs;terior ex earundem differentia oritur.

Solis igitur & Lunæ in Æquatore ver&longs;antium & mediocriter a
Terra di&longs;tantium &longs;unto vires S & L, & erit L+S ad L-S ut
45 ad 25, &longs;eu 9 ad 5.

In portu PlymuthiÆ&longs;tus maris (ex ob&longs;ervatione Samuelis Cole­
pre&longs;&longs;i) ad pedes plus minus &longs;exdecim altitudine mediocri attolli­
tur, ac tempore verno & autumnali altitudo Æ&longs;tus in Syzygiis &longs;u­
perare pote&longs;t altitudinem ejus in Quadraturis, pedibus plus &longs;eptem
vel octo.

Si maxima harum altitudinum differentia &longs;it pedum no­
vem, erit L+S ad L-S ut 20 1/2 ad 11 1/2 &longs;eu 41 ad 23. Quæ
proportio &longs;atis congruit cum priore.

Ob magnitudinem Æ&longs;tus in
portu Bi&longs;toliæ,ob&longs;ervationibus Sturmiimagis fidendum e&longs;&longs;e vi­
detur, ideoQ.E.D.nec aliquid certius con&longs;titerit, proportionem 9
ad 5 u&longs;urpabimus.

Cæterum ob aquarum reciprocos motus, Æ&longs;tus maximi non in­
cidunt in ip&longs;as Luminarium Syzygias, &longs;ed &longs;unt tertii a Syzygiis
ut dictum fuit, &longs;eu proxime &longs;equuntur tertium Lunæ po&longs;t Syzy­
gias appul&longs;um ad meridianum loci, vel potius (ut a Sturmiono­
tatur) &longs;unt tertii po&longs;t diem novilunii vel plenilunii, &longs;eu po&longs;t ho-
ram a novilunio vel plenilunio plus minus duodecimam, adeoque
incidunt in horam a novilunio vel plenilunio plus minus quadra­
ge&longs;imam tertiam.

Incidunt vero in hoc portu in horam &longs;epti­
mam circiter ab appul&longs;u Lunæ ad meridianum loci; ideoque pro­
xime &longs;equuntur appul&longs;um Lunæ ad meridianum, ubi Luna di&longs;tat a
Sole vel ab oppo&longs;itione Solis gradibus plus minus octodecim vel
novendecim in con&longs;equentia.

Æ&longs;tas & Hyems maxime vigent,
non in ip&longs;is Sol&longs;titiis, &longs;ed ubi Sol di&longs;tat a Sol&longs;titiis decima circi­
ter parte totius circuitus, &longs;eu gradibus plus minus 36 vel 37. Et
&longs;imiliter maximus Æ&longs;tus maris oritur ab appul&longs;u Lunæ ad meri­
dianum loci, ubi Luna di&longs;tat a Sole decima circiter parte motus
totius ab Æ&longs;tu ad Æ&longs;tum.

Sit di&longs;tantia illa graduum plus mi­
nus 18 1/2. Et vis Solis in hac di&longs;tantia Lunæ a Syzygiis & Qua­
draturis, minor erit ad augendum & ad minuendum motum ma­
ris a vi Lunæ oriundum, quam in ip&longs;is Syzygiis & Quadraturis, in
ratione radii ad &longs;inum complementi di&longs;tantiæ hujus duplicatæ &longs;eu
anguli graduum 37, hoc e&longs;t, in ratione 10000000 ad 7986355.
IdeoQ.E.I. analogia &longs;uperiore pro S &longs;cribi debet 0, 7986355 S.

in gradu 18 1/2 po&longs;t Quadraturas, in declinatione graduum plus

Et Luminaris ab Æquatore declinantis
vis ad Mare movendum diminuitur in duplicata ratione &longs;inus

Et propterea vis
Lunæ in his Quadraturis e&longs;t tantum 0,8570327 L.

E&longs;t igitur
L+0,7986355 S ad 0,8570327 L-0,7986355 S ut 9 ad 5.

Et di&longs;tantiæ ejus in gradu 18 1/2 a

ad vim in mediocri di&longs;tantia, ut 0,9830427 & 1,017522 ad 1. Unde fit

Corol.1. Cum Aqua vi Solis agitata a&longs;cendat ad altitudinem
pedis unius & undecim digitorum cum octava parte digiti, eadem
vi Lunæ a&longs;cendet ad altitudinem octo pedum & digitorum octo,
& vi utraque ad altitudinem pedum decem cum &longs;emi&longs;&longs;e, & ubi
Luna e&longs;t in Perigæo ad altitudinem pedum duodecim cum &longs;emi&longs;&longs;e
& ultra, præ&longs;ertim ubi Æ&longs;tus ventis &longs;pirantibus adjuvatur.

Tanta
autem vis ad omnes Maris motus excitandos abunde &longs;ufficit, &
quantitati motuum probe re&longs;pondet.

Nam in maribus quæ ab
Oriente in Occidentem late patent, uti in Mari Pacifico,& Maris
Atlantici& Æthiopicipartibus extra Tropicos, aqua attolli &longs;o­
let ad altitudinem pedum &longs;ex, novem, duodecim vel quindecim.

In Mari autem Pacifico,quod profundius e&longs;t & latius patet, Æ&longs;tus
dicuntur e&longs;&longs;e majores quam in Atlantico& Æthiopico.Etenim
ut plenus &longs;it Æ&longs;tus, latitudo Maris ab Oriente in Occidentem non
minor e&longs;&longs;e debet quàm graduum nonaginta.

In Mari Æthiopico,
a&longs;cen&longs;us aquæ intra Tropicos minor e&longs;t quam in Zonis tempera­
tis, propter angu&longs;tiam Maris inter Africam& Au&longs;tralem partem
Americæ.In medio Mari aqua nequit a&longs;cendere, ni&longs;i ad littus
utrumque & orientale & occidentale &longs;imul de&longs;cendat: cum tamen
vicibus alternis ad littora illa in Maribus no&longs;tris angu&longs;tis de&longs;cen­
dere debeat.

Ea de cau&longs;a fluxus & refluxus in In&longs;ulis, quæ à
littoribus longi&longs;&longs;ime ab&longs;unt, perexiguus e&longs;&longs;et &longs;olet.

In Portubus
quibu&longs;dam, ubi aqua cum impetu magno per loca vado&longs;a, ad
Sinus alternis vicibus implendos & evacuandos, influere & effluere
cogitur, fluxus & refluxus debent e&longs;&longs;e &longs;olito majores, uti ad
Plymuthum& pontem Chep&longs;towæin Anglia; ad montes S. Mi­
chaelis& urbem Abrincatuorum(vulgo Auranches) in Normania;
ad Cambaiam& Peguin Indiaorientali.

His in locis mare,
magna cum velocitate accedendo & recedendo, littora nunc in­
undat nunc arida relinquit ad multa milliaria.

NeQ.E.I.petus
influendi & remeandi prius frangi pote&longs;t, quam aqua attollitur

Et par e&longs;t
ratio fretorum oblongorum & vado&longs;orum, uti Magellanici& ejus
quo Angliacircundatur.

Æ&longs;tus in huju&longs;modi portubus & fretis,
per impetum cur&longs;us & recur&longs;us &longs;upra modum augetur.

Ad littora
vero quæ de&longs;cen&longs;u præcipiti ad mare profundum & apertum

PROPOSITIO XXXVIII. PROBLEMA XIX.
Invenire Figuram corporis Lunæ.

Si corpus Lunare fluidum e&longs;&longs;et ad in&longs;tar Maris no&longs;tri, vis Terræ
ad fluidum illud in partibus & citimis & ultimis elevandum, e&longs;&longs;et
ad vim Lunæ, qua Mare no&longs;trum in partibus & &longs;ub Luna & Lunæ
oppo&longs;itis attollitur, ut gravitas acceleratrix Lunæ in Terram ad
gravitatem acceleratricem Terræ in Lunam & diameter Lunæ ad
diametrum Terræ conjunctim; id e&longs;t, ut 39,371 ad 1 & 100 ad
365 conjunctim, &longs;eu 1079 ad 100. Unde cum Mare no&longs;trum vi
Lunæ attollatur ad pedes 8 2/3, fluidum Lunare vi Terræ attolli de­
beret ad pedes 93 1/2. EaQ.E.D. cau&longs;a Figura Lunæ Sphærois e&longs;&longs;et,
cujus maxima diameter producta tran&longs;iret per centrum Terræ, &
&longs;uperaret diametros perpendiculares exce&longs;&longs;u pedum 187. Talem
igitur Figuram Luna affectat, eamque &longs;ub initio induere debuit.
que E. I.

Idem colligitur ex curvatura viæ Cometarum.

Pergunt hæc
corpora propemodum in circulis maximis quamdiu moventur cele­
rius; at in fine cur&longs;us, ubi motus apparentis pars illa quæ à pa­
rallaxi oritur, majorem habet proportionem ad motum totum ap­
parentem, deflectere &longs;olent ab his circulis, & quoties Terra mo­
vetur in unam partem, abire in partem contrariam.

Oritur hæc
deflexio maxime ex Parallaxi, propterea quod re&longs;pondet motui
Terræ; & in&longs;ignis ejus quantitas, meo computo, collocavit di&longs;pa­
rentes Cometas &longs;atis longe infra Jovem.

Unde con&longs;equens e&longs;t
quod in Perigæis & Periheliis, ubi propius ad&longs;unt, de&longs;cendunt
&longs;æpius infra orbes Martis & inferiorum Planetarum.

LIBER
TERTIUS.
Confirmatur etiam propinquitas Cometarum ex luce capitum.

Nam corporis cœle&longs;tis a Sole illu&longs;trati & in regiones longinquas
abeuntis, diminuitur &longs;plendor in quadruplicata ratione di&longs;tantiæ:
in duplicata ratione videlicet ob auctam corporis di&longs;tantiam a
Sole, & in alia duplicata ratione ob diminutam diametrum appa­
rentem.

Unde &longs;i detur & lucis quantitas & apparens diameter
Cometæ, dabitur di&longs;tantia, dicendo quod di&longs;tantia &longs;it ad di&longs;tan­
tiam Planetæ, in ratione diametri ad diametrum directe & ratione
&longs;ubduplicata lucis ad lucem inver&longs;e.

Sic minima capillitii Co­
metæ anni 1682 diameter, per Tubum opticum &longs;exdecim pedum
a Flam&longs;tedioob&longs;ervata & Micrometro men&longs;urata, æquabat 2′.

Nucleus autem &longs;eu &longs;tella in medio capitis vix decimam partem la­
titudinis hujus occupabat, adeoque lata erat tantum 11″ vel 12″.

Luce vero & claritate capitis &longs;uperabat caput Cometæ anni 1680,
&longs;tella&longs;que primæ vel &longs;ecundæ magnitudinis æmulabatur.

Ponamus
Saturnum cum annulo &longs;uo qua&longs;i quadruplo lucidiorem fui&longs;&longs;e: &
quoniam lux annuli propemodum æquabat lucem globi inter­
medii, & diameter apparens globi &longs;it qua&longs;i 21″, adeoque lux
globi & annuli conjunctim æquaret lucem globi, cujus diameter
e&longs;&longs;et 30″: erit di&longs;tantia Cometæ ad di&longs;tantiam Saturni ut 1 ad √ 4
inver&longs;e, & 12″ ad 30″ directe, id e&longs;t, ut 24 ad 30 &longs;eu 4 ad 5.
Rur&longs;us Cometa anni 1665 men&longs;e Aprili,ut author e&longs;t Hevelius,
claritate &longs;ua pene Fixas omnes &longs;uperabat, quinetiam ip&longs;um Satur­
num, ratione coloris videlicet longe vividioris.

Quippe lucidior
erat hic Cometa altero illo, qui in fine anni præcedentis apparu­
erat & cum &longs;tellis primæ magnitudinis conferebatur.

Latitudo
capillitii erat qua&longs;i 6′, at nucleus cum Planetis ope Tubi optici
collatus, plane minor erat Jove, & nunc minor corpore interme-
dio Saturni, nunc ip&longs;i æqualis judicabatur.

Porro cum diameter
capillitii Cometarum raro &longs;uperet 8′ vel 12′, diameter vero nu­
clei &longs;eu &longs;tellæ centralis &longs;it qua&longs;i decima vel forte decima quinta
pars diametri capillitii, patet Stellas ha&longs;ce ut plurimum eju&longs;dem
e&longs;&longs;e apparentis magnitudinis cum Planetis.

Unde cum lux earum
cum luce Saturni non raro conferri po&longs;&longs;it, eamque aliquando &longs;u­
peret; manife&longs;tum e&longs;t quod Cometæ omnes in Periheliis vel in­
fra Saturnum collocandi &longs;int, vel non longe &longs;upra.

Errant igitur
toto cœlo qui Cometas in regionem Fixarum prope ablegant: qua
certe ratione non magis illu&longs;trari deberent a Sole no&longs;tro, quam
Planetæ, qui hic &longs;unt, illu&longs;trantur a Stellis fixis.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Hæc di&longs;putavimus non con&longs;iderando ob&longs;curationem Cometa­
rum per &longs;umum illum maxime copio&longs;um & cra&longs;&longs;um, quo caput
circundatur, qua&longs;i per nubem obtu&longs;e &longs;emper lucens.

Nam quan­
to ob&longs;curius redditur corpus per hunc fumum, tanto propius ad
Solem accedat nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t, ut copia lucis a &longs;e reflexa Planetas æmu­
letur.

Inde veri&longs;imile fit Cometas longe infra &longs;phæram Saturni
de&longs;cendere, uti ex Parallaxi probavimus.

Idem vero quam ma­
xime confirmatur ex Caudis.

Hæ vel ex reflexione fumi &longs;par&longs;i
per Æthera, vel ex luce capitis oriuntur.

Priore ca&longs;u minuenda
e&longs;t di&longs;tantia Cometarum, ne fumus a capite &longs;emper ortus per
&longs;patia nimis ampla incredibili cum velocitate & expan&longs;ione pro­
pagetur.

In po&longs;teriore referenda e&longs;t lux omnis tam caudæ quam
capillitii ad nucleum capitis.

Igitur &longs;i concipiamus lucem hanc
omnem congregari & intra di&longs;cum nuclei coarctari, nucleus ille
jam certe, quoties caudam maximam & fulgenti&longs;&longs;imam emittit,
Jovem ip&longs;um &longs;plendore &longs;uo multum &longs;uperabit.

Minore igitur
cum diametro apparente plus lucis emittens, multo magis illu&longs;tra­
bitur a Sole, adeoque erit Soli multo propior.

Quinetiam capita
&longs;ub Sole delite&longs;centia, & caudas cum maximas tum fulgenti&longs;&longs;imas
in&longs;tar trabium ignitarum nonnunquam emittentia, eodem argu­
mento infra orbem Veneris collocari debent.

Nam lux illa omnis
&longs;i in &longs;tellam congregari &longs;upponatur, ip&longs;am Venerem ne dicam Ve­
neres plures conjunctas quandoque &longs;uperaret.

Idem denique colligitur ex luce capitum cre&longs;cente in rece&longs;&longs;u
Cometarum a Terra Solem ver&longs;us, ac decre&longs;cente in eorum rece&longs;&longs;u
a Sole ver&longs;us Terram.

Sic enim Cometa po&longs;terior Anni 1665
(ob&longs;ervante Hevelio,) ex quo con&longs;pici cœpit, remittebat &longs;emper
de motu &longs;uo apparente, adeoque præterierat Perigæum; Splen­
dor vero capitis nihilominus indies cre&longs;cebat, u&longs;Q.E.D.m Cometa
radiis Solaribus obtectus de&longs;iit apparere.

Cometa Anni 1683,
ob&longs;ervante eodem Hevelio,in fine Men&longs;is Juliiubi primum con­
&longs;pectus e&longs;t, tardi&longs;&longs;ime movebatur, minuta prima 40 vel 45 circi­
ter &longs;ingulis diebus in Orbe &longs;uo conficiens.

Ex eo tempore motus
ejus diurnus perpetuo augebatur u&longs;que ad Sept.4. quando eva&longs;it
graduum qua&longs;i quinque.

Igitur toto hoc tempore Cometa ad
Terram appropinquabat.

Id quod etiam ex diametro capitis
Micrometro men&longs;urata colligitur: quippe quam Heveliusreperit
Aug.6. e&longs;&longs;e tantum 6′.
5″ inclu&longs;a coma, at Sept.2. e&longs;&longs;e 9′.

Caput igitur initio longe minus apparuit quam in &longs;ine motus, at
initio tamen in vicinia Solis longe lucidius extitit quam circa
finem, ut refert idem Hevelius.Proinde toto hoc tempore, ob
rece&longs;&longs;um ip&longs;ius a Sole, quoad lumen decrevit, non ob&longs;tante ac­
ce&longs;&longs;u ad Terram.

Cometa Anni 1618 circa medium Men&longs;is De­
cembris,& i&longs;te Anni 1680 circa finem eju&longs;dem Men&longs;is, celerrime
movebantur, adeoque tunc erant in Perigæis.

Verum &longs;plendor
maximus capitum contigit ante duas fere &longs;eptimanas, ubi modo
exierant de radiis Solaribus; & &longs;plendor maximus caudarum
paulo ante, in majore vicinitate Solis.

Caput Cometæ prioris,
juxta ob&longs;ervationes Cy&longs;ati, Decemb.1. majus videbatur &longs;tellis pri­
mæ magnitudinis, & Decemb.16. (jam in Perigæo exi&longs;tens) mag­
nitudine parum, &longs;plendore &longs;eu claritate luminis plurimum defe­
cerat. Jan.7. Keplerusde capite incertus finem fecit ob&longs;ervandi.

Die 12 men&longs;is Decemb.con&longs;pectum & a Flam&longs;tedioob&longs;ervatum
e&longs;t caput Cometæ po&longs;terioris, in di&longs;tantia novem graduum a Sole;
id quod &longs;tellæ tertiæ magnitudinis vix conce&longs;&longs;um fui&longs;&longs;et. Decemb.
15. & 17 apparuit idem ut &longs;tella tertiæ magnitudinis, diminutum
utique &longs;plendore Nubium juxta Solem occidentem. Decemb.26.
veloci&longs;&longs;ime motus, inque Perigæo propemodum exi&longs;tens, cedebat
ori Pega&longs;i, Stellæ tertiæ magnitudinis. Jan.3. apparebat ut Stella
quartæ, Jan.9. ut Stella quintæ, Jan.13. ob &longs;plendorem Lunæ
cre&longs;centis di&longs;paruit. Jan.25. vix æquabat Stellas magnitudinis
&longs;eptimæ.

Si &longs;umantur æqualia a Perigæo hinc inde tempora, ca­
pita quæ temporibus illis in longinquis regionibus po&longs;ita, ob
æquales a Terra di&longs;tantias, æqualiter lucere debui&longs;&longs;ent, in plaga
Solis maxime &longs;plenduere, ex altera Perigæi parte evanuere.

Igi­
tur ex magna lucis in utroque &longs;itu differentia, concluditur magna
Solis & Cometæ vicinitas in &longs;itu priore.

Nam lux Cometarum
regularis e&longs;&longs;e &longs;olet, & maxima apparere ubi capita veloci&longs;&longs;ime
moventur, atque adeo &longs;unt in Perigæis; ni&longs;i quatenus ea major
e&longs;t in vicinia Solis.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE
Corol.1. Splendent igitur Cometæ luce Solis a &longs;e reflexa.

Corol.2. Ex dictis etiam intelligitur cur Cometæ tantopere fre­
quentant regionem Solis.

Si cernerentur in regionibus longe
ultra Saturnum, deberent &longs;æpius apparere in partibus Soli oppo­
&longs;itis.

Forent enim Terræ viciniores qui in his partibus ver&longs;a­
rentur, & Sol interpo&longs;itus ob&longs;curaret cæteros.

Verum percur­
rendo hi&longs;torias Cometarum, reperi quod quadruplo vel quintuplo
plures detecti &longs;unt in Hemi&longs;phærio Solem ver&longs;us, quam in He­
mi&longs;phærio oppo&longs;ito, præter alios procul dubio non paucos quos
lux Solaris obtexit.

Nimirum in de&longs;cen&longs;u ad regiones no&longs;tras
neque caudas emittunt, neque adeo illu&longs;trantur a Sole, ut nudis
oculis &longs;e prius detegendos exhibeant, quam &longs;int ip&longs;o Jove pro­
piores.

Spatii autem tantillo intervallo circa Solem de&longs;cripti
pars longe major &longs;ita e&longs;t a latere Terræ quod Solem re&longs;picit;
inque parte illa majore Cometæ, Soli ut plurimum viciniores,
magis illuminari &longs;olent.

Corol.3. Hinc etiam manife&longs;tum e&longs;t, quod Cœli re&longs;i&longs;tentia de­
&longs;tituuntur.

Nam Cometæ vias obliquas & nonnunquam cur&longs;ui
Planetarum contrarias &longs;ecuti, moventur omnifariam liberrime, &
motus &longs;uos etiam contra cur&longs;um Planetarum, diuti&longs;&longs;ime con&longs;er­
vant.

Fallor ni genus Planetarum &longs;int, & motu perpetuo in or­
bem redeant.

Nam quod Scriptores aliqui Meteora e&longs;&longs;e volunt,
argumentum a capitum perpetuis mutationibus ducentes, funda­
mento carere videtur.

Capita Cometarum Atmo&longs;phæris ingen­
tibus cinguntur; & Atmo&longs;phæræ inferne den&longs;iores e&longs;&longs;e debent.

Unde nubes &longs;unt, non ip&longs;a Cometarum corpora, in quibus muta­
tiones illæ vi&longs;untur.

Sic Terra &longs;i e Planetis &longs;pectaretur, luce nu­
bium &longs;uarum proculdubio &longs;plenderet, & corpus firmum &longs;ub nu­
bibus prope delite&longs;ceret.

Sic cingula Jovis in nubibus Planetæ
illius formata e&longs;t, quæ &longs;itum mutant inter &longs;e, & firmum Jovis
corpus per nubes illas difficilius cernitur.

Et multo magis cor­
pora Cometarum &longs;ub Atmo&longs;phæris & profundioribus & cra&longs;&longs;iori­
bus ab&longs;condi debent.

axibus majoribus de&longs;cribentes, tardius revolventur.

Ut &longs;i axis Or­
bis Cometæ &longs;it quadruplo major axe Orbis Saturni, tempus revo­

annos 30, ut 4 √ 4 (&longs;eu 8) ad 1, ideoque erit annorum 240.

Ponamus radium Orbis magni, &longs;eu Ellip&longs;eos

partes 2432747, & motu horario partes 10136. In majoribus
autem vel minoribus di&longs;tantiis, motus tum diurnus tum horarius
erit ad hunc motum diurnum & horarium in &longs;ubduplicata ratione
di&longs;tantiarum reciproce, ideoQ.E.D.tur.

Corol.4. Unde &longs;i Latus rectum Parabolæ quadruplo majus &longs;it
radio Orbis magni, & quadratum radii illius ponatur e&longs;&longs;e partium
100000000: area quam Cometa radio ad Solem ducto &longs;ingulis die­
bus de&longs;cribit, erit partium 1216373 1/4, & &longs;ingulis horis area illa
erit partium 50682 1/4. Sin latus rectum majus &longs;it vel minus in ra­
tione quavis, erit area diurna & horaria major vel minor in ea­
dem ratione &longs;ubduplicata.
