tur, ut & eæ Galletii: meliores &longs;unt eæ quæ per po&longs;itiones Co­
metæ ad fixas a Montenaro, Hookio, Angone& Ob&longs;ervatore in
Nova-Anglia,& nonnunquam a Ponthæo& Cellio&longs;unt factæ.

Jam collatis Ob&longs;ervationibus inter &longs;e, colligere videor quod
Cometa hoc men&longs;e circulum fere maximum de&longs;crip&longs;it, &longs;ecantem
Eclipticam in 25. 12′, idQ.E.I. angulo 3gr. 12′ quamproxime.

Nam & MontenarusOrbitam ab Ecliptica in au&longs;trum, tribus &longs;al-
tem gradibus declina&longs;&longs;e dicit.

Et cognita cur&longs;us po&longs;itione, lon­
gitudines Cometæ ex ob&longs;ervationibus collectæ, ad incudem jam
revocari po&longs;&longs;unt & melius nonnunquam determinari, ut &longs;it in &longs;e­
quentibus. CelliusNovemb.

17. ob&longs;ervavit di&longs;tantiam Cometæ a
Spica , æqualem e&longs;&longs;e di&longs;tantiæ ejus a &longs;tella lucida in dextra ala
Corvi: & hinc locandus e&longs;t Cometa in inter&longs;ectione hujus circuli
quem Cometa motu apparente de&longs;crip&longs;it, cum circulo maximo
qui a fixis illis duabus æqualiter di&longs;tat, atque adeo in 7gr. 54′,
cum latitudine au&longs;trali 43′.

Præterea Montenarus, Novemb.20.
hora &longs;exta matutina Venetiis,Cometam vidit non totis quatuor
gradibus di&longs;tantiam a Spica; dicitque hanc di&longs;tantiam, vix æqua&longs;&longs;e
di&longs;tantiam &longs;tellarum duarum lucidarum in alis Corvi, vel duarum
in juba Leonis, hoc e&longs;t 3gr. & 30′ vel 32′.

Sit igitur di&longs;tantia
Cometæ a Spica 3gr. 30′, & Cometa locabitur in 22gr. 48′, cum
latitudine au&longs;trali 1gr. 30′.

Adhæc Montenarus, Novemb.21, 22,
24 & 25 ante ortum Solis, Sextante æneo quintupedali ad mi­
nuta prima & &longs;emiminuta divi&longs;o & vitris Tele&longs;copicis armato,
di&longs;tantias men&longs;uravit Cometæ a Spica 8gr 28′, 13gr. 10′, 23gr.
30′, & 28gr. 13′: & has di&longs;tantias, per refractionem nondum cor­
rectas, addendo longitudini Spicæ, collegit Cometam his tempo­
ribus fui&longs;&longs;e in 27gr. 51′, 2gr. 33′, 12gr. 52′ & 17gr. 45′.

Si di&longs;tantiæ illæ per refractiones corrigantur, & ex di&longs;tantiis cor­
rectis differentiæ longitudinum inter Spicam & Cometam probe
deriventur, locabitur Cometa his temporibus in 27gr. 52′,
2gr. 36′, 12gr. 58′ & 17gr. 53′ circiter.

Latitudines au­
tem ad has longitudines in via Cometæ captas, prodeunt 1 gr. 45′,
1gr. 58′, 2gr. 22′ & 2gr. 31′.

Harum quatuor ob&longs;ervationum ho­
ras matutinas Montenarusnon po&longs;uit.

Priores duæ ante ho­
ram &longs;extam, po&longs;teriores (ob viciniam Solis) po&longs;t &longs;extam factæ
videntur.

Die 22, ubi Cometa ex ob&longs;ervatione Montenariloca­
tur in 2gr. 36′, Hookiusno&longs;ter eundem locavit in 3gr. 30′
ut &longs;upra. Montenarusin defectu, Hookiusin exce&longs;&longs;u erra&longs;&longs;e viden­
tur.

Nam Cometa, ex &longs;erie ob&longs;ervationum, jam fuit in 3gr. 56′
vel 3gr. circiter.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Ob&longs;ervationum &longs;uarum ultimam inter vapores & diluculum
captam, Montenarus&longs;u&longs;pectam habebat.

Et Celliuseodem tem­
pore (id e&longs;t, Novem.25) Cometam per ejus Altitudinem & Azi­
muthum locavit in 15gr. 47′, cum latitudine au&longs;trali qua&longs;i gra­
dus unius Sed Celliusob&longs;ervavit etiam eodem tempore, quod
Cometa erat in linea recta cum &longs;tella lucida in dextro &longs;emore
Virginis & cum Lance au&longs;trali Libræ, & hæc linea &longs;ecat viam
Cometæ in 18gr. 36′. Ponthæusetiam eodem tempore ob&longs;er­
vavit, quod Cometa erat in recta tran&longs;eunte per Chelam au&longs;tri
nam Scorpii & per &longs;tellam quæ Lancem borealem &longs;equitur: &
hæc recta &longs;ecat viam Cometæ in 16gr. 34′.

Ob&longs;ervavit etiam,
quod Cometa erat in recta tran&longs;eunte per &longs;tellam &longs;upra Lancem
au&longs;tralem Libræ & &longs;tellam in principio pedis &longs;ecundi Scorpii: &
hæc recta &longs;ecat viam Cometæ in 17gr. 55′.

Et inter longitu­
dines ex his tribus Ob&longs;ervationibus &longs;ic derivatas, longitudo me­
diocris e&longs;t 17gr. 42′, quæ cum ob&longs;ervatione Montenari&longs;atis
congruit.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

Erravit igitur Celliusjam locando Cometam in 15gr. 47′,
per ejus Azimuthum & Altitudinem.

Et &longs;imilibus Azimuthorum
& Altitudinum ob&longs;ervationibus, Cellius& Ponthæusnon minus
erraverunt locando Cometam in 20 & 24 diebus duobus
&longs;equentibus, ubi &longs;tellæ fixæ ob diluculum vix aut ne vix quidem
apparuere.

Et corrigendæ &longs;unt hæ ob&longs;ervationes per additionem
duorum graduum, vel duorum cum &longs;emi&longs;&longs;e.

Ex omnibus autem Ob&longs;ervationibus inter &longs;e collatis & ad meri­
dianum Londinireductis, colligo Cometam huju&longs;modi cur&longs;um
quamproxime de&longs;crip&longs;i&longs;&longs;e.
Loca autem Cometæ in Orbe Parabolice computata, ita &longs;e habent.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Congruunt igitur Ob&longs;ervationes A&longs;tronomicæ, tam men&longs;e No­
vembriquam men&longs;ibus quatuor &longs;equentibus, cum motu Cometæ
circum Solem in Trajectoria hacce Parabolica, atque adeo unum
& cundem Cometam fui&longs;&longs;e, qui men&longs;e Novembriad Solem de&longs;cen­
dir, & men&longs;ibus &longs;equentibus ab vodem a&longs;cendit, abunde confir­
mant, ut & hunc Cometam in Trajectoria hacce Parabolica dela­
tum fui&longs;&longs;e quamproxime.

Men&longs;ibas Decembri, Januario, Fe­
bruario& Martio,ubi Ob&longs;ervationes hujus Cometæ &longs;unt &longs;atis ac­
curatæ, congruunt eædem cum motu ejus in hac Trajectoria, non
minus accurate quam ob&longs;ervationes Planetarum congruere &longs;olent
cum eorum Theoriis.

Men&longs;e Novembri,ubi ob&longs;ervationes &longs;unt
cra&longs;&longs;æ, errores non &longs;unt majores quam qui cra&longs;&longs;itudini ob&longs;erva­
tionum tribuantur.

Trajectoria Cometæ bis &longs;ecuit planum Eclip­
ticæ, & propterea non fuit rectilinea.

Eclipticam &longs;ecuit non in
oppo&longs;itis cœli partibus, &longs;ed in fine Virginis & principio Capri­
corni, intervallo graduum 98 circiter; ideoque cur&longs;us Cometæ
plurimum deflectebatur a Circulo maximo.

Nam & men&longs;e No­
vembricur&longs;us ejus tribus &longs;altem gradibus ab Ecliptica in au&longs;trum
declinabat, & po&longs;tea men&longs;e Decembrigradibus 29 vergebat ab
Ecliptica in &longs;eptentrionem, partibus duabus Orbitæ in quibus
Cometa tendebat in Solem & redibat a Sole, angulo apparente
graduum plus triginta ab invicem declinantibus, ut ob&longs;ervavit
Montenarus.Pergebat hic Cometa per &longs;igna fere novem, a Vir­
ginis &longs;cilicet duodecimo gradu ad principium Geminorum, præ­
ter &longs;ignum Leonis per quod pergebat antequam videri cœpit: &
nulla alia extat Theoria, qua Cometa tantam Cœli partem motu
regulari percurrat.
Motus ejus fuit maxime inæquabilis.

Nam
circa diem vige&longs;imum Novembris,de&longs;crip&longs;it gradus circiter quin­
que &longs;ingulis diebus; dein motu retardato inter Novemb.26 &
Decemb.12, &longs;patio &longs;cilicet dierum quindecim cum &longs;emi&longs;&longs;e, de­
&longs;crip&longs;it gradus tantum 40; po&longs;tea vero motu iterum accelerato,
de&longs;crip&longs;it gradus fere quinque &longs;ingulis diebus, antequam motus
iterum retardari cœpir.

Et Theoria quæ motui tam inæquabili
per maximam cœli partem probe re&longs;pondet, quæque ea&longs;dem ob­
&longs;ervat leges cum Theoria Planetarum, & cum accuratis ob&longs;erva­
tionibus A&longs;tronomicis accurate congruit, non pote&longs;t non e&longs;&longs;e vera.

Cometa tamen &longs;ub finem motus deviabat aliquantulum ab hac
Trajectoria Parabolica ver&longs;us axem Parabolæ, ut ex erroribus mi­
nuti unius primi duorumve in latitudinem men&longs;e Februario&
Martiocon&longs;pirantibus, colligere videor; & propterea in Orbe El-
liptico circum Solem movebatur, &longs;patio annorum plu&longs;quam quin­

gentorum, quantum ex erroribus illis judicare licuit, revolutio­
nem peragens.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

Cæterum Trajectoriam quam Cometa de&longs;crip&longs;it, & Caudam
veram quam &longs;ingulis in locis projecit, vi&longs;um e&longs;t annexo &longs;chemate
in plano Trajectoriæ optice delineatas exhibere: Ob&longs;ervationibus
&longs;equentibus in Cauda definienda adhibitis.

Nov.17 Cauda gradus amplius quindecim longa Ponthæoap­
paruit. Nov.18 Cauda 30gr. longa, SoliQ.E.D.recte oppo&longs;ita in
Nova-Angliacernebatur, & protendebatur u&longs;que ad &longs;tellam ,
quæ tunc erat in 9gr. 54′. Nov.19 in Mary-Landcauda vi&longs;a
fuit gradus 15 vel 20 longa. Dec.10 Cauda (ob&longs;ervante Flam&longs;tedio)
tran&longs;ibat per medium di&longs;tantiæ inter caudam &longs;erpentis Ophiuchi &
&longs;tellam d in Aquilæ au&longs;trali ala, & de&longs;inebat prope &longs;tellas A, w, bin
Tabulis Bayeri.Terminus igitur erat in gr. 19 1/2gr. cum latitudine
boreali 34 1/4gr. circiter. Dec.11 &longs;urgebat ad u&longs;que caput Sagittæ
(Bayero,a, b,) de&longs;inens in gr. 26gr. 43′, cum latitudine boreali
38gr. 34′. Dec.13 tran&longs;ibat per medium Sagittæ, nec longe ultra
protendebatur, de&longs;inens in=4gr., cum latitudine boreali 42 1/2gr. circi­
ter.
Intelligenda &longs;unt hæc de longitudine caudæ clarioris.

Nam luce
ob&longs;curiore, in cœlo for&longs;an magis &longs;ereno, cauda Dec.12, hora 5, 40′
Romæ(ob&longs;ervante Ponthæo) &longs;upra Cygni Uropygium ad gradus 10
&longs;e&longs;e extulit; atque ab hac &longs;tella ejus latus ad occa&longs;um & boream
min.
45 de&longs;titit.

Lata autem erat cauda his diebus gradus 3, juxta
terminum &longs;uperiorem, ideoque medium ejus di&longs;tabat a Stella illa
2gr 15′ au&longs;trum ver&longs;us, & terminus &longs;uperior erat in gr. 22gr. cum
latitudine boreali 61gr.. Dec.21 &longs;urgebat fere ad cathedram Ca&longs;&longs;io­
peiæ,æqualiter di&longs;tans a b & Schedir,& di&longs;tantiam ab utraque
di&longs;tantiæ earum ab invicem æqualem habens, adeoQ.E.D.&longs;inens
in gr. 24gr. cum latitudine 47 1/2gr.. Dec.29 tangebat Scheat&longs;itam ad
&longs;ini&longs;tram, & intervallum &longs;tellarum duarum in pede boreali Andro­
medæaccurate complebat, & longa erat 54gr. adeoQ.E.D.&longs;inebat
in 8 19gr. cum latitudine 35gr.. Jan.5 tetigit &longs;tellam p in pectore
Andromedæ,ad latus &longs;uum dextrum, & &longs;tellam m in ejus cingulo
ad latus &longs;ini&longs;trum; & (juxta Ob&longs;ervationes no&longs;tras) longa erat
40gr.; curva autem erat & convexo latere &longs;pectabat ad au&longs;trum.

Cum circulo per Solem & caput Cometæ tran&longs;eunte angulum
confecit graduum 4 juxta caput Cometæ; at juxta terminum al­
terum inclinabatur ad circulum illum in angulo 10 vel 11 graduum,
& chorda caudæ cum circulo illo continebat angulum graduum
octo. Jan.13 Cauda luce &longs;atis &longs;en&longs;ibili terminabatur inter Ala­
mech& Algol,& luce tenui&longs;&longs;ima de&longs;inebat e regione &longs;tellæ x in
latere Per&longs;ei.Di&longs;tantia termini caudæ a circulo Solem & Come­
tam ungente erat 3gr. 50′, & inclinatio chordæ caudæ ad circu­
lum illum 8 1/2gr. Jan.25 & 26 luce tenui micabat ad longitu­
dinem graduum 6 vel 7; & ubi cœlum valde &longs;erenum erat, luce
tenui&longs;&longs;ima & ægerrime &longs;en&longs;ibili attingebat longitudinem graduum
duodecim & paulo ultra.

Dirigebatur autem ejus axis ad Luci­
dam in humero orientali Aurigæ accurate, adeoQ.E.D.clinabat ab
oppo&longs;itione Solis boream ver&longs;us in angulo graduum decem.

De­
nique Feb.10 Caudam oculis armatis a&longs;pexi gradus duos lon­
gam.

Nam lux prædicta tenuior per vitra non apparuit. Pon­
thæusautem Feb.7 &longs;e caudam ad longitudinem graduum 12
vidi&longs;&longs;e &longs;cribit.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Orbem jam de&longs;criptum &longs;pectanti & reliqua Cometæ hujus Phæ­
nomena in animo revolventi, haud difficulter con&longs;tabit quod cor­
pora Cometarum &longs;unt &longs;olida, compacta, fixa ac durabilia ad in­
&longs;tar corporum Planetarum.

Nam &longs;i nihil aliud e&longs;&longs;ent quam vapo­
res vel exhalationes Terræ, Solis & Planetarum, Cometa hicce in
tran&longs;itu &longs;uo per viciniam Solis &longs;tatim di&longs;&longs;ipari debui&longs;&longs;et.

E&longs;t enim
calor Solis ut radiorum den&longs;itas, hoc e&longs;t, reciproce ut quadratum
di&longs;tantiæ loeorum a Sole.

Ideoque cum di&longs;tantia Cometæ a cen­
tro Solis Decemb.8 ubi in Perihelio ver&longs;abatur, e&longs;&longs;et ad di&longs;tan­
tiam Terræ a centro Solis ut 6 ad 1000 circiter, calor Solis apud
Cometam eo tempore erat ad calorem Solis æ&longs;tivi apud nos ut
1000000 ad 36, &longs;eu 28000 ad 1. Sed calor aquæ ebullientis e&longs;t
qua&longs;i triplo major quam calor quem terra arida concipit ad æ&longs;ti­
vum Solem, ut expertus &longs;um: & calor ferri candentis (&longs;i recte
conjector) qua&longs;i triplo vel quadruplo major quam calor aquæ ebul­
lientis; adeoque calor quem terra arida apud Cometam in Peri­
helio ver&longs;antem ex radiis Solaribus concipere po&longs;&longs;et, qua&longs;i 2000
vicibus major quam calor ferri candentis.

Tanto autem calore
vapores & exhalationes, omni&longs;que materia volatilis itatim con&longs;umi
ac di&longs;&longs;ipari debui&longs;&longs;ent.

Cometa igitur in Perihelio &longs;uo calorem immen&longs;um ad Solem
concepit, & calorem illum diuti&longs;&longs;ime con&longs;ervare pote&longs;t.

Nam
globus ferri candentis digitum unum latus, calorem &longs;uum omnem
&longs;patio horæ unius in aere con&longs;i&longs;tens vix amitteret.

Globus autem
major calorem diutius con&longs;ervaret in ratione diametri, propterea
quod &longs;uperficies (ad cujus men&longs;uram per contactum aeris ambi-
entis refrigeratur) in illa ration minor e&longs;t pro quantitate mate­
riæ &longs;uæ calidæ inclu&longs;æ.

Ideoque globus ferri candentis huic
Terræ æqualis, id e&longs;t, pedes plus minus 40000000 latus, diebus
totidem, & idcirco annis 50000, vix refrige&longs;ceret.

Su&longs;picor ta­
men quod duratio Caloris, ob cau&longs;as latentes, augeatur in minore
ratione quam ea diametri: & optarim rationem veram per experi­
menta inve&longs;tigari.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

Porro notandum e&longs;t quod Cometa Men&longs;e Decembri,ubi ad
Solem modo incaluerat, caudam emittebat longe majorem &
&longs;plendidiorem quam antea Men&longs;e Novembri,ubi Periheliunt non­
dum attigerat.

Et univer&longs;aliter caudæ omnes maximæ & fulgen­
ti&longs;&longs;imæ e Cometis oriuntur, &longs;tatim po&longs;t tran&longs;itum eorum per regi­
onem Solis.

Conducit igitur calefactio Cometæ ad magnitudi­
nem caudæ.

Et inde colligere videor quod cauda nihil aliud fit
quam vapor longe tenui&longs;&longs;imus, quem caput &longs;eu nucleus Cometæ
per calorem &longs;uum emittit.

Cæterum de Cometarum caudis triplex e&longs;t opinio; eas vel jubar
e&longs;&longs;e Solis per tran&longs;lucida Cometarum capita propagatum, vel oriri
ex refractione lucis in progre&longs;&longs;u ip&longs;ius a capite Comeræ in Ter­
ram, vel denique nubem e&longs;&longs;e &longs;eu vaporem a capite Comeræ jugi­
ter &longs;urgentem & abeuntem in partes a Sole aver&longs;as.

Opinio pri­
ma eorum e&longs;t qui nondum imbuti &longs;unt &longs;cientia rerum Opticarum.

Nam jubar Solis in cubiculo tenebro&longs;o non cernitur, ni&longs;i quatenus
lux reflectitur e pulverum & fumorum particulis per aerem &longs;em­
per volitantibus: adeoQ.E.I. aere fumis cra&longs;&longs;ioribus infecto &longs;plen­
didius e&longs;t, & &longs;en&longs;um fortius ferit; in aere clariore tenuius e&longs;t &
ægrius &longs;entitur: in cœlis autem ab&longs;que materia reflectente nullum
e&longs;&longs;e pote&longs;t.

Lux non cernitur quatenus in jubare e&longs;t, &longs;ed quatenus
inde re&longs;tectitur ad oculos no&longs;tros.

Nam vi&longs;io non &longs;it ni&longs;i per radios
qui in oculos impingunt.

Requiritur igitur materia aliqua reflectens
in regione caudæ, ne cœlum totum luce Solis illu&longs;tratum unifor­
miter &longs;plendeat.
Opinio &longs;ecunda multis premitur difficultatibus.

Caudæ nunquam variegantur coloribus: qui tamen refractionum
&longs;olent e&longs;&longs;e comites in&longs;eparabiles.

Lux Fixarum & Planetarum di­
&longs;tincte ad nos tran&longs;mi&longs;&longs;a, demon&longs;trat medium cœle&longs;te nulla vi re­
fractiva pollere.

Nam quod dicitur Fixas ab Ægyptiiscomatas
nonnunquam vi&longs;as fui&longs;&longs;e, id quoniam rari&longs;&longs;ime contingit, a&longs;cri­
bendum e&longs;t nubium refractioni fortuitæ.

Fixarum quoque radia­
tio & &longs;cintillatio ad refractiones tum Oculorum tum Aeris tre­
muli referendæ &longs;unt: quippe quæ admotis oculo Tele&longs;copiis
evane&longs;cunt, Aeris & a&longs;cendentium vaporum tremore fit ut radii
facile de angu&longs;to pupillæ &longs;patio per vices detorqueantur, de lati­
ore autem vitri objectivi apertura neutiquam.

Inde e&longs;t quod
&longs;cintillatio in priori ca&longs;a generetur, in po&longs;teriore autem ce&longs;&longs;et:
& ce&longs;&longs;atio in po&longs;teriore ca&longs;u demon&longs;trat regularem tran&longs;mi&longs;&longs;ionem
lucis per cœlos ab&longs;que omni refractione &longs;en&longs;ibili.

Nequis con­
tendat quod caudæ non &longs;oleant videri in Cometis cum eorum lux
non e&longs;t &longs;atis fortis, quia tunc radii &longs;ecundarii non habent &longs;itis vi­
rium ad oculos movendos, & propterea caudas Fixarum non cerni:
&longs;ciendum e&longs;t quod lux Fixarum plus centum vicibus augeri pote&longs;t
mediantibus Tele&longs;copiis, nec tamen caudæ cernuntur Planeta­
rum quoque lux copio&longs;ior e&longs;t, caudæ vero nunæ: Comeræ autem
&longs;æpe caudati&longs;&longs;imi &longs;unt, ubi capitum lux tenuis e&longs;t & valde obtu&longs;a:
&longs;ic enim Cometa Anni 1680, Men&longs;e Decembri,quo tempore ca­
put luce &longs;ua vix æquabat &longs;tellas &longs;ecundæ magnitudinis, caudam
emittebat &longs;plendore notabili u&longs;que ad gradus 40, 50, 60 longi­
tudinis & ultra: po&longs;tea Jan.27 & 28 caput apparebat ut &longs;tella
&longs;eptimæ tantum magnitudinis, cauda vero luce quidem pertenui
&longs;ed &longs;atis &longs;en&longs;ibili longa erat 6 vel 7 gradus, & luce ob&longs;curi&longs;&longs;ima,
quæ cerni vix po&longs;&longs;et, porrigebatur ad gradum u&longs;Q.E.D.odecimum
vel paulo ultra: ut &longs;upra dictum e&longs;t.

Sed & Feb.9 & 10 ubi
caput nudis oculis videri de&longs;ierat, caudam gradus duos longam
per Tele&longs;copium contemplatus &longs;um.

Porro &longs;i cauda oriretur ex
refractione materiæ cœle&longs;tis, & pro figura cœlorum deflecteretur
de Solis oppo&longs;itione, deberet deflexio illa in ii&longs;dem cœli regioNI­
bus in eandem &longs;emper partem fieri.

Atqui Cometa Anni 1680
Decemb.28. hora 8 1/2 P.M. Londini,ver&longs;abatur in 8gr. 41′ cum
latitudine boreali 28gr. 6′, Sole exi&longs;tente in 18gr. 26′.

Et Co­
meta Anni 1577, Dec.29 ver&longs;abatur in 8gr. 41′ cum latitu­
dine boreali 28gr. 40′, Sole etiam exi&longs;tente in 18gr. 26′ circi­
ter.

UtroQ.E.I. ca&longs;u Terra ver&longs;abatur in eodem loco, & Co­
meta apparebat in eadem cœli parte: in priori tamen ca&longs;u cauda
Cometæ (ex meis & aliorum Ob&longs;ervationibus) declinabat angulo
graduum 4 1/2 ab oppo&longs;itione Solis aquilonem ver&longs;us; in po&longs;te­
riore vero (ex Ob&longs;ervationibus Tychonis) declinatio erat gra­
duum 21 in au&longs;trum.

Igitur repudiata cœlorum refractione,
&longs;upere&longs;t ut Phænomena Caudarum ex materia aliqua reflectente
deriventur.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Caudas autem a capitibus oriri & in regiones a Sole aver&longs;as
a&longs;cendere confirmatur ex legibus quas ob&longs;ervant.

Ut quod in
planis Orbium Cometarum per Solem tran&longs;euntibus jacentes, de­
viant ab oppo&longs;itione Solis in eas &longs;emper partes, quas capita in
Orbibus iilis progredientia relinquunt.

Quod &longs;pectatori in his
planis con&longs;tituto apparent in partibus a Sole directe aver&longs;is; di­
grediente autem &longs;pe&longs;tatore de his planis, deviatio paulatim &longs;en­
titur, & indies apparet major.

Quod deviatio cæteris paribus
minor e&longs;t ubi cauda obliquior e&longs;t ad Orbem Cometæ, ut & ubi
caput Cometæ ad Solem propius accedit; præ&longs;ertim &longs;i &longs;pectetur
deviationis angulus juxta caput Cometæ.

Præterea quod caudæ
non deviantes apparent rectæ, deviantes autem incurvantur.

Quod
curvatura major e&longs;t ubi major e&longs;t deviatio, & magis &longs;en&longs;ibilis ubi
cauda cæteris paribus longior e&longs;t: nam in brevioribus curvatura
ægre animadvertitur.

Quod deviationis angulus minor e&longs;t juxta
caput Cometæ, major juxta caudæ extremitatem alteram, atque
adeo quod cauda convexo &longs;ui latere partes re&longs;picit a quibus &longs;it
deviatio, quæQ.E.I. recta &longs;unt linea a Sole per caput Cometæ in
infinitum ducta.

Et quod caudæ quæ prolixiores &longs;unt & latiores,
& luce vegetiore micant, &longs;int ad latera convexa paulo &longs;plendi­
diores & limite minus indi&longs;tincto terminatæ quam ad concava.

Pendent igitur Phænomena caudæ a motu capitis, non autem a
regione cœli in qua caput con&longs;picitur; & propterea non fiunt per
refractionem cœlorum, &longs;ed a capite &longs;uppeditante materiam ori­
untur.

Etenim ut in Aere no&longs;tro fumus corporis cuju&longs;vis igniti
petit &longs;uperiora, idque vel perpendiculariter &longs;i corpus quie&longs;cat,
vel oblique &longs;i corpus moveatur in latus: ita in Cœlis ubi corpora
gravitant in Solem, fumi & vapores a&longs;cendere debent à Sole (uti
jam dictum e&longs;t) & &longs;uperiora vel recta petere, &longs;i corpus fumans
quie&longs;cit; vel oblique, &longs;i corpus progrediendo loca &longs;emper de&longs;erit
a quibus &longs;uperiores vaporis partes a&longs;cenderant.

Et obliquitas i&longs;ta
minor erit ubi a&longs;cen&longs;us vaporis velocior e&longs;t: nimirum in vicinia
Solis & juxta corpus fumans.

Ex obliquitatis autem diver&longs;itate
incurvabitur vaporis columna: & quia vapor in columnæ latere
præcedente paulo recentior e&longs;t, ideo etiam is ibidem aliquanto
den&longs;ior erit, lucemque propterea copio&longs;ius reflectet, & limite mi­
nus indi&longs;tincto terminabitur.

De Caudarum agitionibus &longs;ubita­
neis & incertis, deque earum figuris irregularibus, quas nonnulli
quandoQ.E.D.&longs;cribunt hic nihil adjicio; propterea quod vel a
mutationibus Aeris ne&longs;tri, & motibus nubium caudas aliqua ex
parte ob&longs;curantium oriantur; vel forte a partibus Viæ Lacteæ,
quæ cum caudis prætereuntibus confundi po&longs;&longs;int, ac tanquam ea­
rum partes &longs;pectari.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Vapores autem, qui &longs;patiis tam immen&longs;is implendis &longs;ufficiant,
ex Cometarum Atmo&longs;phæris oriri po&longs;&longs;e, intelligetur ex ratitate
Aeris no&longs;tri.

Nam Aer juxta &longs;uperficiem Terræ &longs;patium occupat
qua&longs;i 850 partibus majus quam Aqua eju&longs;dem ponderis, ideoque
Aeris columna cylindrica pedes 850 alta, eju&longs;dem e&longs;t ponderis
cum Aquæ columna pedali latitudinis eju&longs;dem.

Columna autem
Aeris ad &longs;ummitatem Atmo&longs;phæræ a&longs;&longs;urgens æquat pondere &longs;uo
colurnnam Aquæ pedes 33 altam circiter; & propterea &longs;i colum­
næ totius Aereæ pars inferior pedum 850 altitudinis dematur,
pars reliqua &longs;uperior æquabit pondere &longs;uo columnam Aquæ altam
pedes 32. Inde vero (ex Hypothe&longs;i multis experimentis confir­
mata, quod compre&longs;&longs;io Aeris &longs;it ut pondus Atmo&longs;phæræ incum­
bentis, quodque gravitas &longs;it reciproce ut quadratum di&longs;tantiæ lo­
eorum a centro Terræ) computationem per Corol.
Prop.

XXII.
Lib.

II. ineundo, inveni quod Aer, &longs;i a&longs;cendatur a &longs;uperficie
Terræ ad altitudinem &longs;emidiametri unius terre&longs;tris, rarior &longs;it quam
apud nos in ratione longe majori, quam &longs;patii omnis infra Or­
bem Saturni ad globum diametro digiti unius de&longs;criptum.

Ideo­
que globus Aeris no&longs;tri digitum unum latus, ea cum raritate
quam haberet in altitudine &longs;emidiametri unius terre&longs;tris, impleret
omnes Planetarum regiones ad u&longs;que &longs;phæram Saturni & longe
ultra.

Proinde cum Aer adhuc altior in immen&longs;um rare&longs;cat; &
coma &longs;eu Atmo&longs;phæra Cometæ, a&longs;cendendo ab illius centro, qua&longs;i
decuplo altior &longs;it quam &longs;uperficies nuclei, deinde cauda adhuc
altius a&longs;cendat, debebit cauda e&longs;&longs;e quam rari&longs;&longs;ima.

Et quamvis,
ob longe cra&longs;&longs;iorem Cometarum Atmo&longs;phæram, magnamque cor­
porum gravitationem Solem ver&longs;us, & gravitationem particula­
rum Aeris & vaporum in &longs;e mutuo, fieri po&longs;&longs;it ut Aer in &longs;patiis
cœle&longs;tibus inque Cometarum caudis non adeo rare&longs;cat; perexi­
guam tamen quantitatem Aeris & vaporum, ad omnia illa cauda­
rum Phœnomena abunde &longs;ufficere, ex hac computatione per&longs;pi­
cuum e&longs;t.

Nam & caudarum in&longs;ignis raritas colligitur ex a&longs;tris
pes eas tran&longs;lucentibus.

Atmo&longs;phæra terre&longs;tris luce Solis &longs;plen­
dens, cra&longs;&longs;itudine &longs;ua paueorum milliarium, & a&longs;tra omnia & ip­
&longs;am Lunam ob&longs;curat & extinguit penitus: per immen&longs;am vero
caudarum cra&longs;&longs;itudinem, luce pariter Solari illu&longs;tratam, a&longs;tra mi­
nima ab&longs;que claritatis detrimento tran&longs;lucere no&longs;cuntur.

Neque
major e&longs;&longs;e &longs;olet caudarum plurimarum &longs;plendor, quam Aeris no­
&longs;tri in tenebro&longs;o cubiculo latitudine digiti unius duorumve, lucem
Solis in jubare reflectentis.
Quo temporis &longs;patio vapor a capite ad terminum caudæ a&longs;cen­

dit, cogno&longs;ci fere pote&longs;t ducendo rectam a termino caudæ ad So­
lem, & notando locum ubi recta illa Trajectoriam &longs;ecat.

Nam
vapor in termino caudæ, &longs;i recta a&longs;cendat a Sole, a&longs;cendere cœpit
a capite quo tempore caput erat in loco inter&longs;ectionis.

At vapor
non recta a&longs;cendit à Sole, &longs;ed motum Cometæ, quem aute a&longs;cen­
&longs;um &longs;uum habebat, retinendo, & cum motu a&longs;cen&longs;us &longs;ui eundem
componendo, a&longs;cendit oblique.

Unde verior erit Problematis
&longs;olutio, ut recta illa quæ Orbem &longs;ecat, parallela &longs;it longitudini
caudæ, vel potius (ob motum curvilineum Cometæ) ut eadem a
linea caudæ divergat.

Hoc pacto inveni quod vapor qui erat in
termino caudæ Jan.25, a&longs;cendere cœperat a capite ante Dec.11,
adeoque a&longs;cen&longs;u &longs;uo toto dies plus 45 con&longs;ump&longs;erat.

At cauda
illa omnis quæ Dec.10 apparuit, a&longs;cenderat &longs;patio dierum illo­
rum duorum, qui a tempore Perihelii Cometæ elap&longs;i fuerant.

Vapor igitur &longs;ub initio in vicinia Solis celerrime a&longs;cendebat, &
po&longs;tea cum motu per gravitatem &longs;uam &longs;emper retardato a&longs;cen­
dere pergebat; & a&longs;cendendo augebat longitudinem caudæ: cauda
autem quamdiu apparuit ex vapore fere omni con&longs;tabat qui a
tempore Perihelii a&longs;cenderat; & vapor, qui primus a&longs;cendit, &
terminum caudæ compo&longs;uit, non prius evanuit quam ob nimiam
&longs;uam tam a Sole illu&longs;trante quam ab oculis no&longs;tris di&longs;tantiam vi­
deri de&longs;iit.

Unde etiam caudæ Cometarum aliorum quæ breves
&longs;unt, non a&longs;cendunt motu celeri & perpetuo a capitibus & mox
evane&longs;cunt, &longs;ed &longs;unt permanentes vaporum & exhalationum co­
lumnæ, a capitibus lenti&longs;&longs;imo multorum dierum motu propagatæ,
quæ, participando motum illum capitum quem habuere &longs;ub initio,
per cœlos una cum capitibus moveri pergunt.

Et hinc rur&longs;us col­
ligitur &longs;patia cœle&longs;tia vi re&longs;i&longs;tendi de&longs;titui; utpote in quibus non
&longs;olum &longs;olida Planetarum & Cometarum corpora, &longs;ed etiam rari&longs;­
&longs;imi caudarum vapores motus &longs;uos veloci&longs;&longs;imos liberrime peragunt
ac diuti&longs;&longs;ime con&longs;ervant.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

A&longs;cen&longs;um caudarum ex Atmo&longs;phæris capitum & progre&longs;&longs;um in
partes a Sole aver&longs;as Keplerusa&longs;cribit actioni radiorum lucis ma­
teriam caudæ &longs;ecum rapientium.

Et auram longe tenui&longs;&longs;imam in
&longs;patiis liberrimis actioni radiorum cedere, non e&longs;t a ratione pror­
&longs;us alienum, non ob&longs;tante quod &longs;ub&longs;tantiæ cra&longs;&longs;æ, impediti&longs;&longs;imis
in regionibus no&longs;tris, a radiis Solis &longs;en&longs;ibiliter propelli nequeant.

Alius particulas tam leves quam graves dari po&longs;&longs;e exi&longs;timat, &
materiam caudarum levitare, perque levitatem &longs;uam a Sole a&longs;cen-
dere.

Cum autem gravitas corporum terre&longs;trium &longs;it ut materia
in corporibus, ideoque &longs;ervata quantitate materiæ intendi & re­
mitti nequeat, &longs;u&longs;picor a&longs;cen&longs;um illum ex rarefactione materiæ
caudarum potius oriri.

A&longs;cendit fumus in camino impul&longs;u Aeris
cui innatat.

Aer ille per calorem rarefactus a&longs;cendit, ob diminu­
tam &longs;uam gravitatem &longs;pecificam, & fumum implicatum rapit &longs;e­
cum.

Quidni cauda Cometæ ad eundem modum a&longs;cenderit a
Sole?

Nam radii Solares non agitant Media quæ permeant, ni&longs;i
in reflexione & refractione.

Particulæ reflectentes ea actione cale­
factæ calefacient auram ætheream cui implicantur.

Illa calore &longs;ibi
communicato rarefiet, & ob diminutam ea raritate gravitatem
&longs;uam &longs;pecificam qua prius tendebat in Solem, a&longs;cendet & &longs;ecum
rapiet particulas reflectentes ex quibus cauda componitur: Ad
a&longs;cen&longs;um vaporum conducit etiam quod hi gyrantur circa Solem
& ea actione conantur a Sole recedere, at Solis Atmo&longs;phæra &
materia cœlorum vel plane quie&longs;cit, vel motu &longs;olo quem a Solis
rotatione acceperint, tardius gyratur.

Hæ &longs;unt cau&longs;æ a&longs;cen&longs;us
caudarum in vicinia Solis, ubi Orbes curviores &longs;unt, & Cometæ
intra den&longs;iorem & ea ratione graviorem Solis Atmo&longs;phæram con­
&longs;i&longs;tunt, & caudas quam longi&longs;&longs;imas mox emittunt.

Nam caudæ
quæ tunc na&longs;cuntur, con&longs;ervando motum &longs;uum & interea ver&longs;us
Solem gravitando, movebuntur circa Solem in Ellip&longs;ibus pro
more capitum, & per motum illum capita &longs;emper comitabuntur
& iis liberrime adhærebunt.

Gravitas enim vaporum in Solem
non magis efficiet ut caudæ po&longs;tea decidant a capitibus Solem ver­
&longs;us, quam gravitas capitum efficere po&longs;&longs;it ut hæc decidant a cau­
dis.

Communi gravitate vel &longs;imul in Solem cadunt, vel &longs;imul in
a&longs;cen&longs;u &longs;uo retardabuntur; adeoque gravitas illa non impedit,
quo minus caudæ & capita po&longs;itionem quamcunque ad invicem a
cau&longs;is jam de&longs;criptis, aut aliis quibu&longs;cunque, facillime accipiant &
po&longs;tea liberrime &longs;ervent.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Caudæ igitur quæ in Cometarum Periheliis na&longs;cuntur, in regi­
ones longinquas cum eorum capitibus abibunt, & vel inde po&longs;t
longam annorum &longs;eriem cum ii&longs;dem ad nos redibunt, vel potius
ibi rarefactæ paulatim evane&longs;cent.

Nam po&longs;tea in de&longs;cen&longs;u capi­
tum ad Solem caudæ novæ breviu&longs;culæ lento motu a capitibus
propagari debebunt, & &longs;ubinde, in Periheliis Cometarum illorum
qui adu&longs;que Atmo&longs;phæram Solis de&longs;cendunt, in immen&longs;um au­
geri.

Vapor enim in &longs;patiis illis liberrimis perpetuo rare&longs;cit ac
dilatatur.

Qua ratione fit ut cauda omnis ad extremitatem &longs;upe-
riorem latior &longs;it quam juxta caput Cometæ.

Ea autem rarefacti­
one vaporem perpetuo dilatatum diffundi tandem & &longs;pargi per
cœlos univer&longs;os, deinde paulatim in Planetas per gravitatem &longs;uam
attrahi & cum eorum Atmo&longs;phæris mi&longs;ceri, rationi con&longs;entaneum
videtur.

Nam quemadmodum Maria ad con&longs;titutionem Terræ
hujus omnino requiruntur, idque ut ex iis per calorem Solis va­
pores copio&longs;e &longs;atis excitentur, qui vel in nubes coacti decidant
in pluviis, & terram omnem ad procreationem vegetabilium irri­
gent & nutriant; vel in frigidis montium verticibus conden&longs;ati
(ut aliqui cum ratione philo&longs;ophantur) decurrant in fontes &
flumina &longs;ic ad con&longs;ervationem marium & humorum in Planetis,
requiri videntur Cometæ, ex quorum exhalationibus & vapori­
bus conden&longs;atis, quicquid liquoris per vegetationem & putre­
factionem con&longs;umitur & in terram aridam convertitur, continuo
&longs;uppleri & refici po&longs;&longs;it.

Nam vegetabilia omnia ex liquoribus
omnino cre&longs;cunt, dein magna ex parte in terram aridam per pu­
trefactionem abeunt, & limus ex liquoribus putrefactis perpetuo
decidit.

Hinc moles Terræ aridæ indies augetur, & liquores, ni&longs;i
aliunde augmentum &longs;umerent, perpetuo decre&longs;cere deberent, ac
tandem deficere.

Porro &longs;u&longs;picor Spiritum illum, qui Aeris no&longs;tri
pars minima e&longs;t &longs;ed &longs;ubtili&longs;&longs;ima & optima, & ad rerum omnium
vitam requiritur, ex Cometis præcipue venire.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

Atmo&longs;phæræ Cometarum in de&longs;cen&longs;u eorum in Solem, excur­
rendo in caudas, diminuuntur, & (ea certe in parte quæ Solem
re&longs;picit) angu&longs;tiores redduntur: & vici&longs;&longs;im in rece&longs;&longs;u eorum a
Sole, ubi jam minus excurrunt in caudas, ampliantur; &longs;i modo
Phænomena eorum Heveliusrecte notavit.

Minimæ autem ap­
parent ubi capita jam modo ad Solem calefacta in caudas maximas
& fulgenti&longs;&longs;imas abiere, & nuclei fumo for&longs;an cra&longs;&longs;iore & nigriore
in Atmo&longs;phærarum partibus infimis circundantur.

Nam fumus
omnis ingenti calore excitatus, cra&longs;&longs;ior & nigrior e&longs;&longs;e &longs;olet.

Sic
caput Cometæ de quo egimus, in æqualibus a Sole ac Terra di­
&longs;tantiis, ob&longs;curius apparuit po&longs;t Perihelium &longs;uum quam antea.

Men&longs;e enim Decembricum &longs;tellis tertiæ magnitudinis conferri &longs;ole­
bat, at Men&longs;e Novembricum &longs;tellis primæ & &longs;ecundæ.

Et qui
utrumque viderant, majorem de&longs;cribunt Cometam priorem.

Nam
Juveni cuidam Cantabrigien&longs;i, Novemb.19, Cometa hicce luce &longs;ua
quantumvis plumbea & obtu&longs;a, æquabat Spicam Virginis, & cla­
rius micabat quam po&longs;tea.

Et D. Storerliteris quæ in manus no­
&longs;tras incidere, &longs;crip&longs;it caput ejus Men&longs;e Decembri,ubi caudam
maximam & fulgenti&longs;&longs;imam emittebat, parvum e&longs;&longs;e & magnitu­
dine vi&longs;ibili longe cedere Cometæ, qui Men&longs;e Novembriante
Solis ortum apparuerat.

Cujus rei rationem e&longs;&longs;e conjectabatur,
quod materia capitis &longs;ub initio copio&longs;ior e&longs;&longs;et, & paulatim con­
&longs;umeretur.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Eodem &longs;pectare videtur quod capita Cometarum aliorum, qui
caudas maximas & fulgenti&longs;&longs;imas emi&longs;erunt, apparuerint &longs;ubob­
&longs;cura & exigua.
Nam Anno 1668 Mart.5. St.
nov.

hora &longs;eptima
ve&longs;pertina R. P.

Vaientinus E&longs;tancius, Bra&longs;iliæagens, Cometam
vidit Horizonti proximum ad occa&longs;um Solis brumalem, capite
minimo & vix con&longs;oicuo, cauda vero &longs;upra modum fulgente, ut
&longs;tantes in littore &longs;peciem ejus e mari reflexam facile cernerent.

Speciem utique habebat trabis &longs;plendentis longitudine 23 gra­
duum, ab occidente in au&longs;trum vergens, & Horizonti fere para­
lela.

Tantus autem &longs;plendor tres &longs;olum dies durabat, &longs;ubinde
notabiliter decre&longs;cens; & interea decre&longs;cente &longs;plendore aucta e&longs;t
magnitudine cauda.

Unde etiam in Portugalliaquartam fere
cœli partem (id e&longs;t, gradus 45) occupa&longs;&longs;e dicitur, ab occidente in
orientem &longs;plendore cum in&longs;igni proten&longs;a; nec tamen tota apparuit,
capite &longs;emper in his regionibus infra Horizontem delite&longs;cente.

Ex incremento caudæ & decremento &longs;plendoris manife&longs;tum e&longs;t
quod caput a Sole rece&longs;&longs;it, eique proximum fuit &longs;ub initio, pro
more Cometæ anni 1680. Et &longs;imilis legitur Cometa anni 1101
vel 1106, cujus Steila erat parva & ob&longs;cura(ut ille anni 1680)
&longs;ed &longs;plendor qui ex ea exivit valde clarus & qua&longs;i ingens trabs ad
Orientem & Aquilonem tendebat,ut habet Heveliusex Simeone
Dunelmen&longs;iMonacho.

Apparuit initio Men&longs;is Februarii,circa ve­
&longs;peram, ad occa&longs;um Solis brumalem.

Inde vero & ex &longs;itu caudæ col­
ligitur caput fui&longs;&longs;e Soli vicinum. A Sole,inquit Matthæus Pari­
&longs;ien&longs;is, di&longs;tabat qua&longs;i cubito uno, ab hora tertia[rectius &longs;exta] u&longs;­
que ad horam nonam radium ex &longs;e longum emittens.Talis etiam
erat ardenti&longs;&longs;imus ille Cometa ab Ari&longs;totelede&longs;criptus Lib.
l.
Meteor.

6. cujus caput primo die non con&longs;pectum e&longs;t, eo quod ante
Solem vel &longs;altem &longs;ub radiis &longs;olaribus oceidi&longs;&longs;et, &longs;equente vero die
quantum potuit vi&longs;um e&longs;t.

Nam quam minima fieri pote&longs;t di&longs;tantia
Solem reliquit, & mox occubuit.

Ob nimium ardorem[caudæ &longs;cili­
cet] nondum apparebat capitis &longs;par&longs;us ignis, &longs;ed procedente tem­
pore(ait Ari&longs;toteles) cum[cauda] jam minus flagraret, reddita
e&longs;t[capiti] Cometæ &longs;ua facies.

Et &longs;plendorem &longs;uum ad tertiam
u&longs;que cæli partem[id e&longs;t, ad 60gr.] extendit.

Apparuit autem
tempore hyberno, & a&longs;cendens u&longs;que ad cingulum Orionis ibi evanuit.
Cometa ille anni 1618, qui c radiis Solaribus caudati&longs;&longs;imus emer&longs;it,
&longs;tellas primæ magnitudinis æquare vel paulo &longs;uperare videbatur,
&longs;ed majores apparuere Cometæ non pauci qui caudas breviores
habuere.

Horum aliqui Jovem, alii Venerem vel etiam Lunam
æqua&longs;&longs;e traduntur.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

Diximus Cometas e&longs;&longs;e genus Planetarum in Orbibus valde ec­
centricis circa Solem revolventium.

Et quemadmodum e Plane­
tis non caudatis, minores e&longs;&longs;e &longs;olent qui in Orbibus minoribus &
Soli propioribus gyrantur, &longs;ic etiam Cometas, qui in Perihcliis
&longs;uis ad Solem propius accedunt, ut plurimum minores e&longs;&longs;e, ne
Solem attractione &longs;ua nimis agitent, rationi con&longs;entaneum videtur.

Orbium vero tran&longs;ver&longs;as diametros & revolutionum tempora
periodica, ex collatione Cometarum in ii&longs;dem Orbibus po&longs;t longa
temporum intervalla redeuntium, determinanda relinquo.

Interea
huic negotio Propo&longs;itio &longs;equens lumen accendere pote&longs;t.
PROPOSITIO XLII. PROBLEMA XXII.
Trajectoriam Cometæ Graphice inventam corrigere.

Oper.1. A&longs;&longs;umatur po&longs;itio plani Trajectoriæ, per Propo&longs;itio­
nem &longs;uperiorem Graphice inventa; & &longs;eligantur tria loca Cometæ
ob&longs;ervationibus accurati&longs;&longs;imis de&longs;inita, & ab invicem quam ma­
xime di&longs;tantia; &longs;itque A tempus inter primam & &longs;ecundam, ac
B tempus inter &longs;ecundam ac tertiam.

Cometam autem in eorum
aliquo in Perigæo ver&longs;ari convenit, vel &longs;altem non longe a Peri­
gæo abe&longs;&longs;e.

Ex his locis apparentibus inveniantur, per opera­
tiones Trigonometricas, loca tria vera Cometæ in a&longs;&longs;umpto illo
plano Trajectoriæ.

Deinde per loca illa inventa, circa centrum
Solis ceu umbilicum, per operationes Arithmeticas, ope Prop.
XXI. Lib.

I. in&longs;titutas, de&longs;cribatur Sectio Conica: & ejus areæ,
radiis a Sole ad loca inventa ductis terminatæ, &longs;unto D & E;
nempe D area inter ob&longs;ervationem primam & &longs;ecundam, & E
area inter &longs;ecundam ac tertiam.

Sitque T tempus totum quo
area tota D+E, velocitate Cometæ per Prop.
XVI. Lib.

I. in­
venta, ce&longs;cribi debet.

Oper.2. Augeatur longitudo Nodorum Plani Trajectoriæ, ad­
ditis ad longitudinem illam 20′ vel 30′, quæ dicantur P; & &longs;er­
vetur plani illius inclinatio ad planum Eclipticæ.

Deinde ex
prædictis tribus Cometæ locis ob&longs;ervatis, inveniantur in hoc novo
plano loca tria vera (at &longs;upra:) deinde etiam Orbis per loca
illa tran&longs;iens, & eju&longs;dem areæ duæ inter ob&longs;ervationes de&longs;criptæ,
quæ &longs;int d& e,nec non tempus totum tquo area tota d+ede­
&longs;cribi debeat.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Oper.3. Servetur Longitudo Nodorum in operatione prima, &
augeatur inclinatio Plani Trajectoriæ ad planum Eclipticæ, addi­
tis ad inclinationem illam 20′ vel 30′, quæ dicantur que Deinde
ex ob&longs;ervatis prædictis tribus Cometæ locis apparentibus, inve­
niantur in hoc novo Plano loca tria vera, Orbi&longs;que per loca
illa tran&longs;iens, ut & eju&longs;dem areæ duæ inter ob&longs;ervationes de­
&longs;criptæ, quæ &longs;int d & e, & tempus totum t quo area tota d+e
de&longs;cribi debeat.

Jam &longs;it C ad I ut A ad B, & G ad 1 ut D ad E, & gad 1 ut
dad e,& g ad 1 ut d ad e; &longs;itque S tempus verum inter ob&longs;erva­
tionem primam ac tertiam; & &longs;ignis + & -probe ob&longs;ervatis
quærantur numeri m& n,ea lege, ut &longs;it 2G-2C=mG-mg+
nG-ng, & 2T-2S æquale mT-mt+nT-nt.

Et &longs;i, in
operatione prima, I de&longs;ignet inclinationem plani Trajectoriæ ad
planum Eclipticæ, & K longitudinem Nodi alterutrius, erit
I+nQ vera inclinatio Plani Trajectoriæ ad Planum Eclipticæ, &
K+mP vera longitudo Nodi.

Ac denique &longs;i in operatione
prima, &longs;ecunda ac tertia, quantitates R, r& r de&longs;ignent Latera
recta Trajectoriæ, & quantitates 1/L, 1/l,1/l eju&longs;dem Latera tran&longs;­
ver&longs;a re&longs;pective: erit R+mr-mR+nr-nR verum Latus re­
ctum, & (1/L+ml-mL+nl-nL) verum Latus tran&longs;ver&longs;um Tra­
jectoriæ quam Cometa de&longs;cribit.

Dato autem Latere tran&longs;ver&longs;o
datur etiam tempus periodicum Cometæ. Q.E.I.

Cæterum Cometarum revolventium tempora periodica, & Or­
bium latera tran&longs;ver&longs;a, haud &longs;atis accurate determinabuntur, ni&longs;i
per collationem Cometarum inter &longs;e, qui diver&longs;is temporibus ap­
parent.

Si plures Cometæ, po&longs;t æqualia temporum intervalla,
eundem Orbem de&longs;crip&longs;i&longs;&longs;e reperiantur, concludendum erit hos
omnes e&longs;&longs;e unum & eundem Cometam, in eodem Orbe revolven­
tem.

Et tum demum ex revolutionum temporibus, dabuntur Or­
bium latera tran&longs;ver&longs;a, & ex his lateribus determinabuntur Or­
bes Elliptici.

In hunc finem computandæ &longs;unt igitur Cometarum plurium
Traiectoriæ, ex hypothe&longs;i quod &longs;int Parabolicæ.

Nam huju&longs;­
modi Trajectoriæ cum Phænomenis &longs;emper congruent quam­
proxime.

Id liquet, non tantum ex Trajectoria Parabolica Co­
metæ anni 1680, quam cum ob&longs;ervationibus &longs;upra contuli, &longs;ed
etiam ex ea Cometæ illius in&longs;ignis, qui annis 1664 & 1665 appa­
ruit, & ab Hevelioob&longs;ervatus fuit.

Is ex ob&longs;ervationibus &longs;uis
longitudines & latitudines hujus Cometæ computavit, &longs;ed minus
accurate.

Ex ii&longs;dem ob&longs;ervationibus, Halleiusno&longs;ter loca Co­
metæ hujus denuo computavit, & tum demum ex locis &longs;ic inven­
tis Trajectoriam Cometæ determinavit.

Invenit autem ejus No­
dum a&longs;cendentem in II 21gr. 13′.

55″, Inclinationem Orbitæ ad
planum Eclipticæ 21gr. 18′.

40″, di&longs;tantiam Perihelii a Nodo in
Orbita 49gr. 27′.
Perihelium in 8gr. 40′.

30′ cum Lati­
tudine au&longs;trina heliocentrica 16gr. 1′.

Cometam in Perihelio
Novemb.24d.
P. M. tempore æquato Londini,vel 13h.

8′
Gedani,&longs;tylo veteri, & Latus rectum Parabolæ 410286, exi&longs;tente
mediocri Terræ a Sole di&longs;tantia 100000. Quam probe loca
Cometæ in hoc Orbe computata, congruunt cum ob&longs;ervationibus,
patebit ex Tabula &longs;equente ab Halleio&longs;upputata.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

row.cell:
Cometa ab Hookioprope &longs;ecundam
Arictis ob&longs;ervabatur, Mar.1d. 7h. 0′
Loudini,cum

p.s:
Apparuit hic Cometa per men&longs;es tres, &longs;ignaque fere &longs;ex de­
&longs;crip&longs;it, & uno die gradus fere viginti confecit.

Cur&longs;us ejus
a circulo maximo plurimum deflexit, in boream incurvatus; &
motus ejus &longs;ub finem ex retrogrado factus e&longs;t directus.

Et non
ob&longs;tante cur&longs;u tam in&longs;olito, Theoria a principio ad finem cum
ob&longs;ervationibus non minus accurate congruit, quam Theoriæ
Planetarum cum eorum ob&longs;ervationibus congruere &longs;olent, ut in­
&longs;picienti Tabulam patebit.

Subducenda tamen &longs;unt minuta duo
prima circiter, ubi Cometa veloci&longs;&longs;imus fuit; id quod fiet au­
ferendo duodecim minuta &longs;ecunda.

prima ab angulo inter Nodum a&longs;cen­
dentem & Perihelium, &longs;eu con&longs;tituendo angulum illum 49gr.
27′.

Cometæ utriu&longs;que (& hujus & &longs;uperioris) parallaxis
annua in&longs;ignis fuit, & inde demon&longs;tratur motus annuus Terræ in
Orbe magno.

Confirmatur etiam Theoria per motum Cometæ qui apparuit
anno 1683. Hic fuit retrogradus in Orbe cujus planum cum
plano Eclipticæ angulum fere rectum continebat.

Hujus Nodus
a&longs;cendens (computante Halleio) erat in 23gr 23′; Inclinatio
Orbitæ ad Eclipticam 83gr. 11′; Perihelium in II 25gr. 29′.

Loca autem Co­
metæ in hoc Orbe ab Halleiocomputata, & cum locis a Flam­
&longs;tedioob&longs;ervatis collata, exhibentur in Tabula &longs;equente.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

Confirmatur etiam Theoria per motum Cometæ retrogradi qui
apparuit anno 1682. Hujus Nodus a&longs;cendens (computante Hal­
leio) erat in 8 21gr. 16′.

Inclinatio Orbitæ ad planum Eclip­
ticæ 17gr. 56′.
Perihelium in = 2gr. 52′.

Di&longs;tantia peri­
helia a Sole 58328. Et tempus æquatum Perihelii Sept.4d.

Loca vero ex ob&longs;ervationibus Flam&longs;tediicomputata, & cum locis
per Theoriam computatis collata, exhibentur in Tabula &longs;e­
quente.

His exemplis abunde &longs;atis manife&longs;tum e&longs;t, quod motus Come­
tarum per Theoriam a nobis expo&longs;itam non minus accurate ex-
hibentur, quam &longs;olent motus Planetarum per eorum Theovias.

Et
propterea Orbes Cometarum per hanc Theoriam enumerari po&longs;­
&longs;unt, & tempus periodicum Cometæ in quolibet Orbe revolventis
tandem &longs;ciri, & tum demum Orbium Elliptieorum latera tran&longs;­
ver&longs;a & Apheliorum altitudines innote&longs;cent.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Cometa retrogradus qui apparuit anno 1607, de&longs;crip&longs;it Orbem
cujus Nodus a&longs;cendens (computante Halleio) erat in 8 20gr. 21′.
Inclinatio plani Orbis ad planum Eclipticæ erat 17gr. 2′.

Peri­
helium erat in = 2gr. 16′, & di&longs;tantia perihelia a Sole erat 58680,
exi&longs;tente radio Orbis magni 100000. Et Cometa erat in Peri­
helio Octob.16d.

Congruit hic Orbis quamproxime cum
Orbe Cometæ qui apparuit anno 1682. Si Cometæ hi duo fue­
rint unus & idem, revolvetur hic Cometa &longs;patio annorum 75, &
axis major Orbis ejus erit ad axem majorem Orbis magni, ut
√c:75X75 ad 1, &longs;eu 1778 ad 100 circiter.

Et di&longs;tantia aphe­
lia Cometæ hujus a Sole, erit ad di&longs;tantiam mediocrem Terræ a
Sole, ut 35 ad 1 circiter.

Quibus cognitis, haud difficile fuerit
Orbem Ellipticum Cometæ hujus determinare.

Atque hæc ita
&longs;e habebunt &longs;i Cometa, &longs;patio annorum &longs;eptuaginta quinque, in
hoc Orbe po&longs;thac redierit.

Cometæ reliqui majori tempore re­
volvi videntur & altius a&longs;cendere.

Cæterum Cometæ, ob magnum eorum numerum, & magnam
Apheliorum a Sole di&longs;tantiam, & longam moram in Apheliis, per
gravitates in &longs;e mutuo nonnihil turbari debent, & eorum eccen­
tricitates & revolutionum tempora nunc augeri aliquantulum,
nunc diminui.

Proinde non e&longs;t expectandum ut Cometa idem,
in eodem Orbe & ii&longs;dem temporibus periodicis, accurate redeat.

Sufficit &longs;i mutationes non majores obvenerint, quam quæ a cau&longs;is
prædictis oriantur.

Et hinc ratio redditur cur Cometæ non comprehendantur Zo­
diaco (more Planetarum) &longs;ed inde migrent & motibus variis in
omnes cœlorum regiones ferantur.

Scilicet eo fine, ut in Apheliis
&longs;uis ubi tardi&longs;&longs;ime moventur, quam longi&longs;&longs;ime di&longs;tent ab invicem
& &longs;e mutuo quam minime trahant.

Qua de cau&longs;a Cometæ qui
altius de&longs;cendunt, adeoque tardi&longs;&longs;ime moventur in Apheliis, de­
bent altius a&longs;cendere.

Cometa qui anno 1680 apparuit, minus di&longs;tabat a Sole in Peri­
helio.

&longs;uo quam parte &longs;exta diametri Solis; & propter &longs;ummam
velocitatem in vicinia illa, & den&longs;itatem aliquam Atmo&longs;phæræ So­
lis, re&longs;i&longs;tentiam nonnullam &longs;entire debuit, & aliquantulum retar-
dari & propius ad Solem accedere: & &longs;ingulis revolutionibus ac­
cedendo ad Solem, incidet is tandem in corpus Solis.

Sed & in
Aphelio ubi tardi&longs;&longs;ime movetur, aliquando per attractionem alio­
rum Cometarum retardari pote&longs;t & &longs;ubinde in Solem incidere.

Sic etiam Stellæ fixæ quæ paulatim expirant in lucern & vapores,
Cometis in ip&longs;as incidentibus refici po&longs;&longs;unt, & novo alimento
accen&longs;æ pro Stellis Novis haberi.

Vapores autem qui ex Sole &
Stellis fixis & caudis Cometarum oriuntur, incidere po&longs;&longs;unt per
gravitatem &longs;uam in Atmo&longs;phæras Planetarum, & ibi conden&longs;ari
& converti in aquam & &longs;piritus humidos, & &longs;ubinde per lentum
calorem in &longs;ales, & &longs;ulphura, & tincturas, & limum, & lutum, &
argillam, & arenam, & lapides, & coralla, & &longs;ub&longs;tantias alias
terre&longs;tres paulatim migrare.

Decre&longs;cente autem corpore Solis
motus medii Planetarum circum Solem paulatim tarde&longs;cent, &
cre&longs;cente Terra motus medius Lunæ circum Terram paulatim au­
gebitur.

Et collatis quidem ob&longs;ervationibus Eclip&longs;ium BabyloNI­
ciscum iis Albategnii& cum hodiernis, Halleiusno&longs;ter motum
medium Lunæ cum motu diurno Terræ collatum, paulatim acce­
lerari, primus omnium quod &longs;ciam deprehendit.

LIBER
TERTIUS.
SCHOLIUM GENERALE.
Hypothe&longs;is Vorticum multis premitur difficultatibus.

Ut Pla­
neta unu&longs;qui&longs;que radio ad Solem ducto areas de&longs;cribat tempori
proportionales, tempora periodica partium Vorticis deberent e&longs;&longs;e
in duplicata ratione di&longs;tantiarum a Sole.

Ut periodica Plane­
tarum tempora &longs;int in proportione &longs;e&longs;quiplicata di&longs;tantiarum a
Sole, tempora periodica partium Vorticis deberent e&longs;&longs;e in eadem
di&longs;tantiarum proportione.

Ut Vortices minores circum Satur­
num, Jovem & alios Planetas gyrati con&longs;erventur & tranquille
natent in Vortice Solis, tempora periodica partium Vorticis So­
laris deberent e&longs;&longs;e æqualia.

Revolutiones Solis & Planetarum cir­
cum axes &longs;uos ab omnibus hi&longs;ce proportionibus di&longs;crepant.

Mo­
tus Cometarum &longs;unt &longs;umme regulares, & ea&longs;dem leges cum Pla­
netarum motibus ob&longs;ervant, & per Vortices explicari nequeunt.

Feruntur Cometæ motibus valde eccentricis in omnes cælorum
partes, quod fieri non pote&longs;t ni&longs;i Vortices tollantur.
Projectilia, in aere no&longs;tro, &longs;olam aeris re&longs;i&longs;tentiam &longs;entiunt.

Sublato aere, ut fit in Vacuo Boyliano,re&longs;i&longs;tentia ce&longs;&longs;at, &longs;iqui­
dem pluma tenuis & aurum &longs;olidum æquali cum velocitate in hoc
Vacuo cadunt.

Et par e&longs;t ratio &longs;patiorum cæle&longs;tium quæ &longs;unt
&longs;upra atmo&longs;phæram Terræ.

Corpora omnia in i&longs;tis &longs;patiis liber­
rime moveri debent; & propterea Planetæ & Cometæ in orbi­
bus &longs;pecie & po&longs;itione datis, &longs;ecundum leges &longs;upra expo&longs;itas, per­
petuo revolvi.

Per&longs;everabunt quidem in orbibus &longs;uis per leges
gravitatis, &longs;ed regularem orbium &longs;itum primitus acquirere per
leges ha&longs;ce minime potuerunt.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Planetæ &longs;ex principales revolvuntur circum Solem in circulis
Soli concentricis, eadem motus directione, in eodem plano quam­
proxime.

Lunæ decem revolvuntur circum Terram, Jovem & Sa­
turnum in circulis concentricis, eadem motus directione, in planis
orbium Planetarum quamproxime.

Et hi omnes motus regulares
originem non habent ex cau&longs;is Mechanicis; &longs;iquidem Cometæ in
Orbibus valde eccentricis, & in omnes cælorum partes libere
feruntur.

Quo motus genere Cometæ per Orbes Planetarum ce­
lerrime & facillime tran&longs;eunt, & in Apheliis &longs;uis ubi tardiores
&longs;unt & diutius morantur, quam longi&longs;&longs;ime di&longs;tant ab invicem,
& &longs;e mutuo quam minime trahunt.

Eleganti&longs;&longs;ima hæcce Solis,
Planetarum & Cometarum compages non ni&longs;i con&longs;ilio & dominio
Entis intelligentis & potentis oriri potuit.

Et &longs;i Stellæ fixæ &longs;int
centra &longs;imilium &longs;y&longs;tematum; hæc omnia &longs;imili con&longs;ilio con&longs;tructa,
&longs;uberunt Uniusdominio: præ&longs;ertim cum lux Fixarum &longs;it eiu&longs;dem
naturæ ac lux Solis, & &longs;y&longs;temata omnia lucem in omnia invicem
immittant.

Hic omnia regit, non ut Anima mundi, &longs;ed ut univer&longs;orum Do­
minus; & propter dominium &longs;uum Dominus Deus
pantiktr dici &longs;olet.

Nam Deuse&longs;t vox relativa
& ad &longs;ervos refertur: & Deitase&longs;t dominatio Dei
non in corpus proprium, &longs;ed in &longs;ervos. Deus &longs;ummuse&longs;t Ens
æternum, infinitum, ab&longs;olute perfectum; &longs;ed Ens utcunque per­
fectum &longs;ine dominio, non e&longs;t Dominus Deus.Dicimus enim Deus
meus, Deus ve&longs;ter, Deus I&longs;raelis:&longs;ed non dicimus Æternus meus,
Æternus ve&longs;ter, Æternus I&longs;raelis; non dicimus Infinitus meus,
Infinitus ve&longs;ter, Infinitus I&longs;raelis; non dicimus Perfectus meus, Per­
fectus ve&longs;ter, Perfectus I&longs;raelis.Hæ appellationes relationem non
habent ad &longs;ervos.

Vox Deuspa&longs;&longs;im &longs;ignificat Dominum,&longs;ed
omnis Dominus non e&longs;t Deus.

Dominatio Entis &longs;piritualis Deum
con&longs;tituit, vera verum, &longs;umma &longs;ummum, ficta fictum.

Et ex do­
minatione vera &longs;equitur, Deum verum e&longs;&longs;e vivum, intelligentem &
potentem; ex reliquis perfectionibus &longs;ummum e&longs;&longs;e vel &longs;umme per-
fectum. Æternuse&longs;t & Infinitus, Omnipotens& Omni&longs;ciens,id
e&longs;t, durat ab æterno in æternum & ade&longs;t ab infinito in infinitum,
omnia regit & omnia cogno&longs;cit quæ fiunt aut &longs;ciri po&longs;&longs;unt.

Non
e&longs;t æternitas vel infinitas, &longs;ed æternus & infinitus; non e&longs;t duratio
vel &longs;patium, &longs;ed durat & ade&longs;t.

Durat &longs;emper & ade&longs;t ubique, &
exi&longs;tendo &longs;emper & ubiQ.E.D.rationem & &longs;patium, æternitatem
& infinitatem con&longs;tituit.

Cum unaquæque &longs;patii particula &longs;it
&longs;emper,& unumquodQ.E.D.rationis indivi&longs;ibile momentum ubique;
certe rerum omnium Fabricator ac Dominus non erit nunquam
nu&longs;quam.Omnipræ&longs;ens e&longs;t nen per virtutem&longs;olam, &longs;ed etiam
per &longs;ub&longs;tantiam: nam virtus &longs;ine &longs;ub&longs;tantia
&longs;ub&longs;i&longs;tere non pote&longs;t.

In ip&longs;o continentur
& moventur univer&longs;a, &longs;ed ab&longs;que mutua pa&longs;­
&longs;ione.Deus nihil patitur ex corporum moti­
bus: illa nullam &longs;entiunt re&longs;i&longs;tentiam ex om­
nipræ&longs;entia Dei.

Deum &longs;ummum nece&longs;&longs;ario
exi&longs;tere in con&longs;e&longs;&longs;o e&longs;t: Et eadem nece&longs;&longs;itate
&longs;empere&longs;t & ubique.Unde etiam totus e&longs;t &longs;ui &longs;imilis, totus oculus,
totus auris, totus cerebrum, totus brachium, totus vis &longs;entiendi,
intelligendi & agendi; &longs;ed more minime humano, more minime
corporeo, more nobis pror&longs;us incognito.

Ut cæcus ideam non
habet colorum, &longs;ic nos ideam non habemus modorum quibus
Deus &longs;apienti&longs;&longs;imus &longs;entit & intelligit omnia.

Corpore omni &
figura corporea pror&longs;us de&longs;tituitur, ideoque videri non pote&longs;t,
nec audiri, nec tangi, nec &longs;ub &longs;pecie rei alicujus corporei coli de­
bet.

Ideas habemus attributorum ejus, &longs;ed quid &longs;it rei alicujus
Sub&longs;tantia minime cogno&longs;cimus.

Videmus tantum corporum figu­
ras & colores, audimus tantum &longs;onos, tangimus tantum &longs;uper­
ficies externas, olfacimus odores &longs;olos, & gu&longs;tamus &longs;apores; In­
timas &longs;ub&longs;tantias nullo &longs;en&longs;u, nulla actione reflexa cogno&longs;cimus, &
multo minus ideam habemus &longs;ub&longs;tantiæ Dei.

Hunc cogno&longs;cimus
&longs;olummodo per proprietates &longs;uas & attributa, & per &longs;apienti&longs;&longs;i­
mas & optimas rerum &longs;tructuras, & cau&longs;as finales; veneramur au­
tem & colimus ob dominium.

Deus enim &longs;ine dominio, provi­
dentia, & cau&longs;is finalibus, nihil aliud e&longs;t quam Fatum & Na­
tura.

Et hæc de Deo; de quo utique ex Phænomenis di&longs;&longs;erere,
ad Philo&longs;ophiem Experimentalempertinet.

LIBER
TERTIUS.

Hactenus Phænomena cælorum & maris no&longs;tri per Vim gravi­
tatis expo&longs;ui, &longs;ed cau&longs;am Gravitatis nondum a&longs;&longs;ignavi.

Oritur
utique hæc Vis a cau&longs;a aliqua quæ penetrat ad u&longs;que centra Solis
& Planetarum, &longs;ine virtutis diminutione; quæque agit non pro
quantitate &longs;uperficierumparticularum in quas agit (ut &longs;olent cau&longs;æ
Mechanicæ,) &longs;ed pro quantitate materiæ &longs;olidæ; & cujus actio in
immen&longs;as di&longs;tantias undique extenditur, decre&longs;cendo &longs;emper in
duplicata ratione di&longs;tantiarum.

Gravitas in Solem componitur
ex gravitatibus in &longs;ingulas Solis particulas, & recedendo a Sole
decre&longs;cit accurate in duplicata ratione di&longs;tantiarum ad u&longs;que or­
bem Saturni, ut ex quiete Apheliorum Planetarum manife&longs;tum e&longs;t,
& ad u&longs;que ultima Cometarum Aphelia, &longs;i modo Aphelia illa
quie&longs;cant.

Rationem vero harum Gravitatis proprietatum ex
Phænomenis nondum potui deducere, & Hypothe&longs;es non &longs;ingo.

Quicquid enim ex Phænomenis non deducitur, Hypothe&longs;isvo­
canda e&longs;t; & Hypothe&longs;es &longs;eu Metaphy&longs;icæ, &longs;eu Phy&longs;icæ, &longs;eu Qua­
litatum occultarum, &longs;eu Mechanicæ, in Philo&longs;ophia Experimentali
locum non habent.

In hac Philo&longs;ophia Propo&longs;itiones deducun­
tur ex Phænomenis, & redduntur generales per Inductionem.

Sie
impenetrabilitas, mobilitas, & impetus corporum & leges motuum
& gravitatis innotuerunt.

Et &longs;atis e&longs;t quod Gravitas revera ex­
i&longs;tat, & agat &longs;ecundum leges a nobis expo&longs;itas, & ad corporum
cæle&longs;tium & maris no&longs;tri motus omnes &longs;ufficiat.

DE MUNDI
SYSTEMATE

Adjicere jam liceret nonnulla de Spiritu quodam &longs;ubtili&longs;&longs;imo cor­
pora cra&longs;&longs;a pervadente, & in ii&longs;dem latente; cujus vi & actionibus
particulæ corporum ad minimas di&longs;tantias &longs;e mutuo attrahunt,
& contiguæ factæ cohærent; & corpora Electrica agunt ad di­
&longs;tantias majores, tam repellendo quam attrahendo corpu&longs;cula vi­
cina; & Lux emittitur, reflectitur, refringitur, inflectitur, & cor­
pora calefacit; & Sen&longs;atio omnis excitatur, & membra Anima­
lium ad voluntatem moventur, vibrationibus &longs;cilicet hujus Spiri­
tus per &longs;olida nervorum capillamenta ab externis &longs;en&longs;uum orga­
nis ad cerebrum & a cerebro in mu&longs;culos propagatis.

Sed hæc
paucis exponi non po&longs;&longs;unt; neque ade&longs;t &longs;ufficiens copia Experi­
mentorum, quibus leges actionum hujus Spiritus accurate deter­
minari & mon&longs;trari debent.
FINIS.
